items.title: Return journey - Day 2
items.summary: I wake up to sunny views across the water and…
items.content_html:
I wake up to sunny views across the water and decide to get a relatively early start to my next destination Alesund. It's only a distance of about 300 km, but since there are two ferry crossings involved in the journey, it does take roughly 5 1/2 hours. As I reach the Alesund area before the check-in time into my next apartment, I decide to go on a little hike to Hogkubben which offers nice views over the fjords and city in the distance. The apartment is a real gem and has a nice garden to relax in.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Return journey - Day 1
items.summary: It's the longest stretch by far, 720 km to near…
items.content_html:
It's the longest stretch by far, 720 km to near Trondheim. After a failed attempt yesterday due to very bad weather, today I am lucky to get a quick glance at the Saltstraumen, the world's largest tidal current. Here, 400 million cubic meters of water flow through in about 6 hours balancing high and low tide between two fjord basins. Even better that there is no one around at this early hour of day. Continuing my journey down South, the weather is very changeable, little sunny spells every now and then, however, mostly pouring rain. With the odd rainbow thrown in for some atmospheric pictures. I see a lot of moose and elk signs along the road, however, none of the buggers show up. After 12 hours on the road I reach my accomodation right by the ocean. However, I am not in the mood for jumping into the waters from my terrace after the long ride. Enjoying the views with a nice glass of white wine instead.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Leaving Lofoten
items.summary: Will the ferry run or won't it? That's the big…
items.content_html:
Will the ferry run or won't it? That's the big question when we get up at 3.15 am. The ferry operator hasn't posted any disruptions on their website, so it's off to Moskenes at 4 am. We are almost alone on the road, only accompanied by the occasional, very heavy shower. Our ferry departs on time, but the ride is getting quite choppy about 30 minutes after leaving the port which makes a lot of passengers run for the paper bags. 

Bodo proves to be a bit of a disappointment but to Medha's delight we find a sports shop that sells the walking trousers she regretted not having bought the other day in Leknes. At 1.30 pm it's time to bid farewell at the airport. Medha is flying back via Bergen to Frankfurt, for me it's the start of my southward journey back to Bergen where I will board the ferry on Sunday.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Lofoten - Last Day
items.summary: It's a windy and rainy last day here on Lofoten.
items.content_html:
It's a windy and rainy last day here on Lofoten. But we couldn't ask for a better place to be in and still enjoy the weather unfolding outside. Frode drops in to bid farewell and shows us a "hidden gem" just around the corner of our house. I am not sure how best to describe this almost cave-like hideaway which was built over the last 11 years by a guy now 81 years old. It's up for sale together with the main house and barn which also has a holiday apartment. Anyone up to grab this special place for around 500.000 EUR? It's a real treat considering the location!

Another treat are the golden eagle and sea eagle we manage to observe flying close to our place and even sitting on a rock right outside our cabin. 

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Lofoten Day 8
items.summary: Today the big question is: where is the sun coming…
items.content_html:
Today the big question is: where is the sun coming out? And is it coming out at all? We are dividing our tasks: I am driving off North towards Austvagoya to do the chasing, Medha takes a walk around Vesterland to wait for it to appear on our little peninsula. We are both in for some treats when it finally breaks through the clouds. Plus another treat in the evening at our secluded beach, diving into the waters at sunset. Thankfully, a hot sauna is waiting for us on return.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Lofoten Day 7
items.summary: We wake up to an overcast sky and low clouds.
items.content_html:
We wake up to an overcast sky and low clouds. The mountains are hiding, and so are we. In our modest abode. It's again midday before we get going. First to Ballstad which proves to be a very boring fishing village. So we turn around on the spot and make our way to Leknes, one of the bigger towns on the Lofoten. There it's coffee and muffin time before we have a short look around the shops and stock up on some provisions. The active part of the day is a walk from Haukland Beach to Utakleiv along the old farmers' route and back via a little pass. It's gloomy weather the whole time; we enjoy it, anyway.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Lofoten Day 6
items.summary: Today is cabin moving day. Or rather the day we…
items.content_html:
Today is cabin moving day. Or rather the day we move from the cabin to the mansion. Frode (does his usefulness ever stop?) has given us a brilliant deal on a house right by the ocean. It's just come up on the market as a new property and apparently the owner wants the first guests to be ultra happy. And ultra happy we'll be in the next 4 days we are staying here, that's for sure. It's just out of this world beautiful, inside and outside. 

Despite all the "ohming" and "ahing" we manage to drag ourselves out for a hike around midday. It starts in Frode's village of Bo, climbs up steeply to a viewpoint over lake Bovatnet and continues from there to a ridge and a little summit right next to it. Medha can smell and hear moose, however, the sightings remain without luck. Non-existent as well is any other human being on this hike. It's just the two of us and stunning nature all around us.

We celebrate our arrival at this special place with a glass of bubbly on a rock near our mansion overlooking the ocean trying to spot orcas. Sadly, we also prove to be unlucky in this endeavour. And it's getting chilly outside, so we are heading back to the premises and heat up our private sauna.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Lofoten Day 5
items.summary: We spend most of the first half of the day…
items.content_html:
We spend most of the first half of the day checking when the rain is likely to stop and where. Having had plans to go West and do a hike there, it's changing plans completely and going East instead as this is where we are most likely going to encounter better weather. Which we do. Hiking up a steep hill high above Henningsvaer but not going all the way to the top as the summit remains in the clouds. The views from up half-way are already spectacular enough, anyway. Getting to watch a helicopter rescue mission. Someone must have injured themselves on the way down. This is definitely no territory for a walk without proper sticks.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Lofoten Day 4
items.summary: Waking up at 06:30 am I decide to go on…
items.content_html:
Waking up at 06:30 am I decide to go on a quick morning hike before the weather starts closing in. Frode (who is becoming kind of indispensable) had recommended a short walk to a viewpoint close to our cabin off the main road. I can sense Odin, the local one-tonner elk, lurking in the bushes but sadly he doesn't make an appearance. Or perhaps just as well in case he hasn't had breakfast yet. Do elks even eat meat? Most likely not.

Medha is opting for a relaxed day at the cottage today, so I decide to drive to Nusfjord and do a coastal hike to Nestland. As coastal paths go, it's a constant up and down. Plus some ladders and chains thrown in. I am quite lucky to not get rained on much, some little drizzly showers are not to be avoided, though. 

In the evening we make use of a little window without rain and roam around the Gimsoy peninsula by car. We find a hike to a shark fin shaped mountain that we might attempt in better weather tomorrow.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: Lofoten Day 3
items.summary: There are clouds in the sky! Out-ra-geous!!! To add more…
items.content_html:
There are clouds in the sky! Out-ra-geous!!! To add more outrageous behaviour to our day, we go on the tourist trail. Which means we drive back towards Reine to do the two most popular Lofoten hikes in one day: Kvalvika Beach and Reinebringen. Thanks to Frode (again), however, it doesn't turn out to be as bad as we fear as he had suggested to hike up Reinebringen in the late afternoon / early evening for the best lights. Which means we start our first hike to Kvalvika when a lot of people are already finished with their program. And on the popular Reinebringen summit I count 8 (!) people when I arrive at the top. Well, there are more coming, but it doesn't feel at all too packed out. And the views are as stunning as promised. Been there (now), done that. What next? Sadly, it looks like it'll be rain. But we'll see. Another Frode promise: it never rains the whole day. It always clears up. It's just the question when. You will read it in tomorrow's post.
